Problem:
Consider a linear transformation system where the initial vector \\(x_0\\) undergoes transformations described by multiplication with matrices. We analyze the sequence where \\(x_0\\) is first multiplied by matrix \\(P\\) and then matrix \\(Q\\) over period t, expressed as \\(x(t) = QP x_0\\). A new transformation matrix \\(R\\) can be used as an intervention.

Given the final state \\(x(T) = QP x_0\\) at some time T, can we determine the initial vector \\(x_0\\) without knowing whether transformations were performed stepwise (first \\(P\\), then \\(Q\\)) or directly as \\(QP\\)?
Explanation: Regardless of how the transformations were applied—either stepwise or directly—the result \\(x(T)\\) remains the same (\\(QP x_0\\)). If \\(QP\\) is invertible, given \\(x(T)\\), one can compute \\(x_0 = (QP)^{-1}x(T)\\), regardless of the method of application of \\(P\\) and \\(Q\\).
